comment.author: 9134056@N05
comment._content:
Are 'chippers' the same as Rivet guns ?
as they seem to be on metal plates.. ?

comment.author: 35740357@N03
comment._content:
Hi cardwellpics,

'Chippers' refer to the workers using the rivet guns, not the actual guns.  So, in fact, these three women appear to be real life Rosie the Riveters.  Thanks for the question!

comment.author: 12929468@N00
comment._content: Due to everyone else standing around in the background, would it be fair to suggest that this was a posed shot during a general break time?

comment.author: 81594342@N00
comment._content: WTF? teh girls working their asses out and the guys standing there like morons FTL

comment.author: 99071700@N00
comment._content:
A chipper must be something other than a riveter - a rivet usually (if not always) goes at 90 degrees to the surface it's going through. These women are holding the tools at a 20-40 degree angle, and a view of the original size will show debris all around them, and in the foreground a bit of curled up steel, and the ends of the tools clearly look like chisels... They must be cleaning up previous assembly process - welding?

It's worth looking at this image at the original size. More details really bring this to life - the looks on the men's faces around the women for instance. it can put your imagination to work trying to figure out who these ladies are, and what it must have been like to be in their shoes.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: "Chippers. Men chipping or smoothing up castings, cutting away metal to make a fit on plates or forms, Using generally an air chipping hammer." from page 103 of books.google.com/books?id=ksl0S6ZgjQwC "The chipper trues up all irregular plates, cuts off plate edges that are too long, smooths rough castings, and cuts out loose rivets. An air tool, similar to that used by the riveter, driving various kinds of chisels, is used for this work as well as for calking." from page 147 of www.archive.org/details/shipbuildingindu00kellrich

comment.author: 99071700@N00
comment._content: Good research Swanq. Thanks for the clarification.
